cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.trajectory: Moving west-northwest across the northern Leeward Islands, then forecast to skirt along or over the Greater Antilles and Bahamas before turning toward the south-central / south-west coast of Florida late this weekend.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Keys or extreme South Florida coast

weather_observation.watch_coast: N/A – no U.S. watches yet issued
weather_observation.warning_coast: N/A – no U.S. warnings yet issued
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Cuba, the Bahamas, and the entire Florida peninsula (including the Gulf Coast near Tampa)
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds are possible with a 27% cumulative chance (up to 7% for 50-kt) peaking around Sunday; hurricane-force gusts (64-kt) have a low (3%) chance but cannot yet be ruled out if the track shifts west.
weather_observation.storm_surge: If Irma tracks up Florida’s west side, on-shore southerly winds could drive a surge well over 3 ft into Tampa Bay, especially around the time of Sunday–Monday high tides.
weather_observation.rainfall: Widespread heavy bands could bring 4–8 inches locally with higher isolated totals, producing urban and low-lying flooding around the port.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Very rough seas and dangerous surf beginning late Saturday; tornadic super-cells possible in outer rain-bands.
